Graph Operations

CausalDynamics.d_separated — Function
d_separated(g, X, Y, Z)

Check if nodes X and Y are d-separated by set Z in directed acyclic graph g.

Arguments

  • g: A directed acyclic graph (DiGraph)
  • X: Source node or set of nodes
  • Y: Target node or set of nodes
  • Z: Conditioning set (set of nodes to condition on)

Returns

  • true if X and Y are d-separated by Z, false otherwise

Examples

using CausalDynamics, Graphs

g = DiGraph(3)
add_edge!(g, 1, 2)  # X → Y
add_edge!(g, 3, 1)  # Z → X
add_edge!(g, 3, 2)  # Z → Y

# X and Y are d-separated by Z (Z blocks the path)
d_separated(g, 1, 2, [3])  # true

# X and Y are not d-separated without conditioning
d_separated(g, 1, 2, [])  # false

References

  • Pearl, J. (2009). Causality, Chapter 1
source
CausalDynamics.get_ancestors — Function
get_ancestors(g, nodes)

Get the set of all ancestors of the given nodes.

An ancestor of node X is any node that has a directed path to X.

Arguments

  • g: Directed acyclic graph
  • nodes: Node or set of nodes

Returns

  • Set of ancestor nodes

Examples

using CausalDynamics, Graphs

g = DiGraph(4)
add_edge!(g, 1, 3)  # X → Z
add_edge!(g, 2, 3)  # Y → Z
add_edge!(g, 3, 4)  # Z → W

ancestors = get_ancestors(g, 4)  # {1, 2, 3}
source
CausalDynamics.get_descendants — Function
get_descendants(g, nodes)

Get the set of all descendants of the given nodes.

A descendant of node X is any node that has a directed path from X.

Arguments

  • g: Directed acyclic graph
  • nodes: Node or set of nodes

Returns

  • Set of descendant nodes

Examples

using CausalDynamics, Graphs

g = DiGraph(4)
add_edge!(g, 1, 2)  # X → Y
add_edge!(g, 1, 3)  # X → Z
add_edge!(g, 2, 4)  # Y → W

descendants = get_descendants(g, 1)  # {2, 3, 4}
source
CausalDynamics.get_parents — Function
get_parents(g, nodes)

Get the set of parents of the given nodes.

Arguments

  • g: Directed acyclic graph
  • nodes: Node or set of nodes

Returns

  • Set of parent nodes
source
CausalDynamics.get_children — Function
get_children(g, nodes)

Get the set of children of the given nodes.

Arguments

  • g: Directed acyclic graph
  • nodes: Node or set of nodes

Returns

  • Set of child nodes
source
CausalDynamics.markov_boundary — Function
markov_boundary(g, Y)

Compute the Markov boundary of node Y.

The Markov boundary of Y is the minimal set that d-separates Y from all other nodes. It consists of: parents of Y, children of Y, and parents of children of Y.

Arguments

  • g: Directed acyclic graph
  • Y: Target node

Returns

  • Set of nodes in the Markov boundary

Examples

using CausalDynamics, Graphs

g = DiGraph(4)
add_edge!(g, 1, 2)  # X → Y
add_edge!(g, 3, 2)  # Z → Y
add_edge!(g, 2, 4)  # Y → W
add_edge!(g, 5, 4)  # V → W

mb = markov_boundary(g, 2)  # {1, 3, 4, 5}
# Parents: {1, 3}
# Children: {4}
# Parents of children: {5}
source
CausalDynamics.find_backdoor_paths — Function
find_backdoor_paths(g, X, Y)

Find all backdoor paths from X to Y.

A backdoor path is a path that starts with an edge pointing into X.

Arguments

  • g: Directed acyclic graph
  • X: Source node
  • Y: Target node

Returns

  • Vector of backdoor paths (each path is a vector of nodes)

Examples

using CausalDynamics, Graphs

g = DiGraph(4)
add_edge!(g, 1, 2)  # Z → X
add_edge!(g, 1, 3)  # Z → Y
add_edge!(g, 2, 3)  # X → Y

# Backdoor path: X ← Z → Y
paths = find_backdoor_paths(g, 2, 3)  # [[1, 3]]
source
CausalDynamics.find_directed_paths — Function
find_directed_paths(g, X, Y)

Find all directed paths from X to Y.

A directed path follows the direction of edges.

Arguments

  • g: Directed acyclic graph
  • X: Source node
  • Y: Target node

Returns

  • Vector of directed paths
source
CausalDynamics.is_dag — Function
is_dag(g)

Check if graph g is a directed acyclic graph (DAG).

Arguments

  • g: Directed graph

Returns

  • true if g is a DAG, false otherwise
source
CausalDynamics.validate_causal_graph — Function
validate_causal_graph(g)

Validate that graph g is a valid causal graph (DAG).

Arguments

  • g: Directed graph

Returns

  • true if valid, throws error if not

Throws

  • ArgumentError if graph is not a DAG
source
CausalDynamics.create_causal_graph — Function
create_causal_graph(edges)

Create a causal graph from a list of edges.

Arguments

  • edges: Vector of tuples (source, target) or dictionary

Returns

  • DiGraph object

Examples

using CausalDynamics

# From edge list
edges = [(1, 2), (3, 1), (3, 2)]
g = create_causal_graph(edges)

# From dictionary
edge_dict = Dict(1 => [2], 3 => [1, 2])
g = create_causal_graph(edge_dict)
source
